title: Late-Stage Private Market Illiquidity
context: Startups stay private longer to avoid public market scrutiny, quarterly earnings pressure, and regulatory burden. The median time to IPO stretched from 4 years (2000) to 12+ years (2024). Founders and VCs celebrate this as strategic patience. But extended private timelines create a liquidity crisis for employees, early investors, and the companies themselves. Employee stock options expire or get taxed before they can be exercised. Early investors are locked in for a decade-plus. And companies build cultures around paper valuations that may never be realized, creating misaligned incentives throughout the organization.
hypothesis: Staying private longer avoids public market pressure and creates better outcomes.

chain.root: Company delays IPO to stay private longer

effects.label: Employee equity becomes illiquid for 8-12+ years
effects.impact: Options expire, tax events without liquidity

children.label: Top talent leaves for companies with liquid equity
Employees take on tax liability for paper gains

effects.label: Secondary markets emerge with steep discounts

children.label: Information asymmetry between insiders and secondary buyers
Company loses control of cap table

effects.label: Paper valuations distort company culture
effects.impact: Decisions optimized for next round, not fundamentals

children.label: Growth at all costs to justify valuation

dontIf: Your employees cannot afford to hold illiquid equity for 10+ years
Your valuation depends on avoiding public market price discovery
ifYouMust: Offer regular tender offers so employees can access partial liquidity
Extend post-departure exercise windows to 5-10 years
Provide transparent valuation updates, not just last-round pricing

alternatives.name: Earlier IPO or direct listing
alternatives.note: Public market discipline with employee liquidity

alternatives.name: Profit sharing
alternatives.note: Cash compensation reduces dependency on equity outcomes
